tagDescription: W.B. Duncan to Mr. Hodgson - with reference to exchange operations.
W. Borski: The Cairo and Fulton Railroad &c.
Duncan, Sherman & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re exchange and commissions in their business.
Thomas A. Doyle, Mayor of Providence to W.B. Duncan: Re. issue of a Water Loan.
S.L.M. Barlow to W. Butler Duncan: Wishes to present a scheme for controlling the payment of the Mississippi State debt.
W.B. Duncan to Kirkman Daniel Hodgson: Details present and predicts future prospects in the South - Commercial, political &c.
George Rose (Gardner, Rose & Co. of Palermo) to Baring Bros. & Co.: Statement of the capital of their firm and asking that their Credit of £10000 be prolonged to the usual period of twelve months.

C.F. Tietgen, to Baring Bros. & Co.: Terms upon which the cession money of seven and one-half million dollars is to be paid to the Danish Government by the United States for the Islands of St. Thomas and St. John in the West Indies.
J.M. Forbes: Refers to effects of elections on the stock market.
W.B. Duncan to Mr. Hodgson: Re sale of Cotton at lowest price of the market.

Duncan, Sherman & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: With regard to the character of their account with them being changed - Asks that they revise the rate of commission which has been raised from 1/8% to 1/4%. Also letter from Barings of 2/8/1870.
C. Morton Stewart to Baring Bros. & Co.: Reports the financial standing of drawers of a Bill referred to him.
J.M. Forbes to T. Baring: Comments on the Joint High Commission. Also newspaper extracts on British-American relations.
J.M. Forbes to Baring Bros. & Co.: Enclosing newspaper extract re Bill to reduce internal taxation.
Moses Harris, Cashier Mechanics' and Traders' Bank, to Baring Bros. & Co.: Concerning a credit requested two years before on a deposit of New Orleans City Consolidated bond for £30000.
John G. Gaines, President Citizens' Bank Louisiana, to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re rate of commission &c in their business with them.
W.H. Swift, President Illinois and Michigan Canal Co., to Baring Bros. & Co. and Matheson & Co.: Report of the annual meeting of the Board of Trustees.

Spofford, Tileston & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re. negotiations for the purpose of placing four million dollars of first mortgage bonds of the Illinois and St. Louis Bridge Co. of St. Louis Mo., on the English market.
Robert Martin: Refers to his securities.
Wm. Butler Duncan to Mr. Hodgson - Re Mississippi Bonds - & the part Mr. Belmont, Rothschild's agent, is taking with regard to them.
A.A. Low & Bros. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Inform them that J.B. Taylor has been appointed their special agent in London.
George Walker and Jacob H. Loud to Baring Bros. & Co.: Respecting the sale of Massachusetts Bonds.
Duncan, Sherman & Co., Bankers: Banking & exchange business.
W.B. Wells (?) to ________ concerning his business operations - Comments on the political situation.
J.M. Forbes: Gives his opinion on the Alabama Claims case. Also Extract from a letter to an English merchant now in Parliament.

J. Watson Webb to Baring Bros. & Co.: Informs them that the Comy. General of the Allied forces on the Paraguay, the Marquis de Caxias has prevented the United States Steamer from passing up to Assuncion to bring home the American Minister, Mr. Washburn and his family.
Wm. Butler Duncan to Mr. Hodgson: Financial and political affairs.
W.B. Duncan to Hodgson: Enquires re money market in England.
W.H. Davidge to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re. sale of Virginia Bonds.
Jay, Cooke & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Desire to open an European account with them. Gives in detail mutual advantages likely to accrue.
W.B. Duncan to Mr. Hodgson: Providence Water Loan &c.
W.H. Davidge to Baring Bros. & Co.: Virginia finances.
C.F. Tietgen: Refers to the sale of the islands of St. Thomas & St. John.
John C. Gaines, President Citizens' Bank, Louisiana, to Baring Bros. & Co: Re exchange operations.
J.M. Forbes to Baring Bros. & Co.: Suggesting an operation in United States Bonds.
Duncan, Sherman & Co., Bankers: Banking & exchange matters.
Weston and Gray to Baring Bros. & Co.: With regard to the effect of the New Tariff on the Sugar market.
C. Mortern Stewart & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Concerning the finances of the City of Baltimore.
J.M. Forbes to T. Baring: Informs him that his partner, Mr. E.J. Hale, is to go to England and will consult with him - The financial and political position.
Granet Brown & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re. credit in favour of Mr. Henry Sprague of New York for their account which has been so long suspended.
C, Morton Stewart & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: His description of the state of affairs founded on a visit to New Orleans.
W.F. Weld & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Instruction re a cargo of Hemp.

A.E. Berie, Secretary of the Navy, to Baring Bros. & Co.: Expressing satisfaction with the transactions between themselves and the Government - and enclosing clipping reflecting upon their House to which the Department pays no attention.
J.M. Forbes: Elections and the stock market.
George L. Foote (Foote & French, Bankers, Boston) to Baring Bros. & Co.: Encloses press copy of Statement of the affairs of Foote & French, successors to Foote & Walker.
Andrew Carnegie: Regrets failure to reach agreement.

S. Abasa to Baring Bros. & Co.: Concerning a project of a submarine telegraph cable from Possiet (the terminus of the Russian telegraph lines on the Japan Sea) to Japan & China - Proposes the formation of a Company in London.
W.H. Davidge to Baring Bros. & Co.: Virginia affairs.
A. Guillemin to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re. opening of an Interoceanic Canal in Central America.
W. Borski to ________ Political and financial condition at home and abroad.
W.H. Davidge to Baring Bros. & Co.: In regard to the law of Virginia and the policy which will prevail as to the debt.
T. Bigelow Lawrence, United States Consul for Italy, to Russell Sturgis: Settlement of account.
Ministry of Finance: C.P. Morton & Co.; Schepeler & Co.
T.R. Waring, South Carolina Loan & Trust Co.; Little hope for the proposed Fire debt loan.
Theodore Hellman, Vice President, Union National Bank of New Orleans, to Baring Bros. & Co.: Making certain requests in behalf of the Union National Bank of New Orleans.
C.F. Tiethgen to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re. Danish purchase.
Wm H. Davidge to Baring Bros. & Co.: Virginia affairs.
Jacob H. Loud, Treasurer to Baring Bros. & Co.: Telegram re Massachusetts Loan.
F.W. Tracy, Treasurer, to Baring Bros. & Co.: Informs them that he has been directed by the Comtee. of Finance to consign the Sterling Loan of the City of Boston to them for sale.
W.B. Duncan to Mr. Hodgson - concerning the cotton business and making suggestions for its better management.
Credit on Brown, Shipley & Co. London.
Duncan Sherman & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Notifying them of an exchange operation with Messrs. M.A. Herrera & Co. of Havana.
W.B. Duncan (Duncan, Sherman & Co.) to Hodgson - Notifies him that they have ordered United States Gold coupons sent to Baring Bros. & Co. Instead of to the Union Bank as formerly.
Fred W. Tracy, Treasurer, Boston, to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re Massachusetts Loan.
John B. Kitching to W.B. Duncan: Re cotton business - enclosed in 3/5/1870.
E.J. Hale (J.M. Forbes & Co.) to T. Baring, M.P.: Enquires as to chance of renewing their loan for another year.
J.M. Forbes: Refers to renewal of loan. Speculation in stocks.
Duncan, Sherman & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Cable messages.
W.B. Duncan, to D.K. Hodgson: Cotton and other business matters.
Geo. S. Cameron, President, The South Carolina Loan & Trust Co.: Loan for five debts.
W.B. Wells to _________ Comments upon the money market both in England and the United States.
P. Cazewood & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co. Re. mode of issue for a fresh amount of Massachusetts Bonds.
W.H. Aspinwall to T. Baring: Political affairs - Grant's pronouncement regarding forming a cabinet.
Wm. Butler Duncan to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re. Mississippi State debt.
R. Hottinguer to T. Baring, M.P.: Re Boston City Loan.
George Martin to Wm. Moir: Application for £20000 of the Massachusetts Loan.

John G. Gaines, President Citizens' Bank of Louisiana, to Baring Bros. & Co.: Asking that their remittances to them night be postponed for a time as confusion has arisen on account of the forgeries of George B. Shute.
W.B. Duncan to Baring Bros. & Co.: Making enquiries as to the value of Emery Mines, from their experience of the mines at Ephesus.

Tiburcio Parrott to J. Stuart Hodgson: Requesting to the informed whether the friendly relations which formerly existed between the Barings and Alsop & Co. their predecessors, are to be continued with the present firm of Parrott & Co.
G. Smith: Introduces Alex. Mitchell of Wisconsin, President of the Chicago & St. Paul Railroad Co.
C. Morton Stewart & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Offering suggestions that would strengthen their position as agents of the State of Maryland.
R.H. Maury & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Enclosing copy of an Act to provide for the funding and payment of the Public Debt.
W.H. Davidge to Baring Bros. & Co.: Virginia finances - Confidential facts re. R.H. Maury & Co. enclosing letter from Governor Walker.
W. Borski: Refers to the Panama canal route.
Duncan, Sherman & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Cipher cable message.
Documents in connection with the Memphis & Ohio Railroad and the Louisville and Nashville Railroad.
J.M. Forbes to T. Baring: The effect of the elections, State and Presidential on United States Bonds.
Andrew Carnegie: Refers to the $5,000,000 of Philadelphia & Erie Railroad bonds.
Duncan, Sherman & Co. to Mr. Hodgson: Franco-Prussian war. General business prospects.
Charles Adams Jr. Treasurer State of Massachusetts, to Baring Bros. & Co.: Preferring a claim for a reduction of the rate of Commission charged on the Massachusetts Bonds.

George S. Boutwell, Secretary of the Treasury, to Baring Bros. & Co.: Informs them that their House, together with the House of Messrs. N.M. Rotheschilds & Sons, Morton, Rose & Co. have been designated as agent of the Government in London for the negotiation of the Bonds of the United States authorized 14/7/1870.

A. Guillemin to Baring Bros. & Co.: Concession has been received from the Government of Nicaragua for opening a Canal between the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans upon the territory of that State, Sketch of a plan for the formation of a Company for the execution of the interoceanic Canal.
Duncan, Sherman & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Cipher cable.
Agents for the Bank of Montreal, New York - Credit for Messrs. Wright & Co. at Rio de Janeiro on the Oriental Bank Corporation, London &c.
W.B. Duncan to K.D. Hodgson: Cotton commissions and the business generally - Enclosing note from John B. Kitching on the same subject.
W.H. Aspinwall to T. Baring: With regard to investment - enclosing letter from General Sherman (Missing)
Duncan, Sherman & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Cotton market - Providence City Water Loan - Railroad Securities &c.
Governor Bullock, Governor of Georgia: Extract from Report of General Ruger on State finances.
John Parrott to [T. Baring]: The Consolidation of his banking business with the London and San Francisco Bank.
W.H. Davidge to Baring Bros. & Co.: Enclosing copy of letter from Governor Walker of Virginia on the finances of the State.
Duncan, Sherman & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Conditions governing advances upon Cotton for the benefit of the joint account.
Duncan, Sherman & Co., Bankers; Exchange operations between Havana, New York & London.
H.D. Newcomb: Loan on collateral security for the Louisville & Nashville Railroad Co. (2 letters).
J.M. Forbes to T. Baring , M.P.: Calling his attention to papers he has sent - Recalls their attitude towards the Alabama question.
C. Morton Stewart to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re bonds of the Western Maryland Railroad guaranteed by the City of Baltimore.
Duncan, Sherman & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Suspension of the firm James Pim & Co. London:- Additions to the key for cipher telegrams.
Charles E.K. Kortright - British Consul at Philadelphia, to T. Baring, M.P.: Enclosing copy of a despatch which he has sent to Rt. Hon. Earl of Clarendon with regard to the inadequacy of his salary.
Henry B. Adams to T. Baring, M.P.: The political state of the country.
C.F. Tietgen: Refers to financial terms of the sale of the Islands of St. Thomas and St. John.
T.B. Lawrence, Consul-General of the United States for Italy to Russell Sturgis.

Maynard Son & Co. (London) to Baring Bros. & Co.: Answering enquiry re the proper form for the Danish Government to give for the receipt of moneys payable to them by the United States for the Islands of St. Thomas and St. John.
W.H. Aspinwall to T. Baring, M.P.: Comments on the projected funding bill - Describes "Pullman Cars" &c en route to California.
J.M. Forbes & Co.: Refers to acceptances of the London, Asiatic & American Co.
W.H. Swift to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re. Illinois and Michigan Canal Bonds.

Thomas R. Waring, Cashier South Carolina, Loan & Trust Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: The President of the Company has been requested by the Governor of the State to open a correspondence re. a Loan, the proceeds to be applied to the payment of the Fire Loan Debt of the State.
Andrew Carnegie to Baring Bros. & Co.: Offering $5000000 1st Mortgage 6% Gold Bonds of the Philadelphia and Erie Railway Co. (Pennsylvania Railroad Co. lessees)
G.C. Ward to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re Cairo and Fulton Railroad - enclosing copy of letter from H.G. Marquand - and also copy of his to Messr. Hope & Co.
W. Butler Duncan to J. Stuart Hodgson: War conditions on the continent affecting trade and exchange. The Cotton Market.
Old New York Accounts - Quarterly Statements of Credit 1842-67 &c. Press Copy.
W.H. Aspinwall to T. Baring: Disappointed that securities offered by his son were not accepted - more about his trip to California &c.
W.B. Duncan to Baring Bros. & Co.: Cotton market - Re. buying on a joint account with them.
Duncan, Sherman & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Cipher telegram.
Duncan, Sherman & Co.: Telegram referring to rumour of advance of the Bank of England rate.
T.B. Lawrence, Consul-General of the United States for Italy, to Mr. Sturgsis. Concerning his account with Baring Bros. & Co.
Duncan, Sherman & Co, to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re cotton purchases on order.
W.B. Duncan to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re. Cotton market.
City of Province, Mass.: "An Ordinance creating a water loan".
E.F. La Villebouvre, President, Union Bank Louisiana, to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re. business operations.
Andrew Carnegie: Refers to Earl of Granville's note, Gladston's speech, American reaction, and his own interests.
Duncan, Sherman & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Cipher telegram.
W.B. Duncan: Part of letter referring to banking business in the Orient.

H.D. Newcomb to Baring Bros. & Co.: Desiring to make a Loan of £60m for which stock in Louisville and Nashville Railroad Co. will be given - Statement re present standing of the Road. See 4/11/1871 (2).
John G. Gaines; Citizens' Bank Louisiana.
F.W. Zachari to T. Baring: Notifies him that he has deeded to S.G. Ward his New Jersey farm of twenty-eight acres, to settle his account with Baring Bros. & Co.
